body.p: As an editor one receives many papers which, honestly, add nothing to what is already known and simply repeat previous work. I was involved in developing prognostic models for stroke outcome 30 years ago, and I regularly receive papers on this with many fewer patients than in my studies – and there are even earlier studies now over 40 years old. I was therefore delighted to receive the systematic review of case-adjustment models published in this issue; I can now refer to it when rejecting non-novel studies! What is disappointing is that only one model has actually been validated properly. Another type of study I often receive concerns Wii Fit, usually reporting a case series showing that people enjoy using it. This is well known (it sells well). Now we have a randomised controlled study that evaluates its specific benefit – and does not demonstrate any major unique benefit. A second popular technology is virtual reality, which is rarely very ‘real’, and a pilot study reported here suggests that a full study is feasible and would require about 80 subjects. Two other trials investigating specific ‘technological’ treatments for specific stroke-related problems – botulinum toxin for leg spasticity and a functional orthosis for shoulder subluxation – are reported here. The orthosis seemed to have a definite benefit, a finding that needs replication but if confirmed, might alter clinical practice. Very interestingly, the study of botulinum toxin did not show any effect on measured spasticity but it did benefit both pain and gait quality suggesting that it may have effects unrelated to spasticity reduction, or that the Ashworth scale is insensitive to clinically relevant change. Another trial reported here also found unexpected benefits from its intervention, using a treadmill. Although the patients with Parkinson’s disease who used the treadmill at home did not show any difference in walking endurance, they did report less fatigue and a better quality of life. Being able to drive is an important factor contributing to quality of life, and people with dementia often are often reluctant to stop. A small pilot study of a specific assessment of driving ability in people with dementia suggests it is worth further study. The abstracts of the (UK) Society for Research in Rehabilitation are published at the end of this issue, illustrating the range of research being undertaken. Finally (and I declare an interest being an author) there is discussion paper exploring the concept and process of adaptation (coping) after acute brain injury using two theoretical models – the WHO ICF biopsychosocial model of illness and a model of goal setting. Please feel free to comment on it and to improve it.
